item.title: Found Poetry
item.description:
Contents

  • Fiberoptic Haiku
  • A stylized bird with an open mouth, tweeting

Fiberoptic Haiku

The admonition on the tag of this fiberoptic cord is broken into three little lines like a haiku.

The text reads:

Insert securely lest
should be detached
in set

The suspension after lest in the first line …

item.title: My Surname
item.description:
My surname is Mallicoat, pronounced like the first two syllables of malady followed by the ordinary word coat.

The Dictionary of American Family Names [1] has these two relevant entries:

Malicoat (250) English: unexplained. Compare MALLICOAT.

Mallicoat (240) English: unexplained. Compare MALICOAT.

It is an uncommon name. The numbers given …

item.title: Carriages
item.description: Webster's Dictionary [1] lists many different types of carriages among its entries. Strangely, it seems to me, most of these are accompanied with illustrations. These always catch my eye as I look up words, so I've gradually become aware of the great diversity in the construction of these vehicles. For …

item.title: Minimalist Websites
item.description:
I like hand-made personal websites, especially those with a minimalist bent, so I've collected some here.

Show Me the Sites

Shared hosting sites crime.team and tilde.club are styled like a terminal window. (Here's a list of some more.)

item.title: Press and Appearances
item.description:
Press and Appearances

  • A reading I gave was covered in Susan Dunne's "Syllable: A Monthly Night Of Words And Music At Little River Restoratives" (Hartford Courant, 28 Nov. 2017).
  • I was profiled in Beach Sloth's "Marshall Mallicoat: Man, Myth, Legend" (23 Mar. 2012).

item.title: Vanitas
item.description:
Grave Plots

My parents came into a couple grave plots. (I don't know how.) They're trying to flip them, since they already have spots reserved. They say that the cemetery in question isn't as desirable as it used to be, so they want to unload them fast. Especially since cremation …
item.dc:creator: Marshall Mallicoat

item.title: John Henry
item.description:
Emails from your boss, written in the form of a question, with a period at the end

Smart people are house slaves to the rich. Even among the aliens, the Nordic whites rule over the little greens and grays. To my landlord, I am an encumbrance on the property. To …
item.dc:creator: Marshall Mallicoat

item.title: Junkie, don't talk to me
item.description:
Cold water after black coffee is like tempering steel

I've come to a calm in the midst of my mid-morning coffee—my first and only coffee of the day. The fog in my head burns off. The wool-legged spiders who cobweb my attic disperse.

Caffeine doesn't bring euphoria—more like …
item.dc:creator: Marshall Mallicoat

item.title: Thoughts on sports
item.description:
Golf

The inner workings of a miniature golf course amount to a secret gospel.

Miniature golf is to golf what reality TV is to reality.

In golf, you swing lowercase L's at the tops of semicolons.

At the bowling alley, they give you golf pencils to keep score.

My grandfather …
item.dc:creator: Marshall Mallicoat

item.title: In the twilight of GMT+1
item.description:
The telegraph was an early internet, with its own lolcats and leetspeak. To people in the future, we probably seem like steampunks: one foot in the last century, carrying our brains around in our pockets like Tamagotchis.

To open a file on your computer, you touch an arrowhead to a …
